discourse_list.title: Macro - Rising bond yields and DAI

content.content: I’ve been asking myself for a while how rising yields on the treasury market and rate hikes could impact Defi and when it would be visable. DAI is especially interesting in this regard. I hope someone could give me an answer to this. The 10y bond yield is a benchmark for me in this game. It has risen from 1.5% (Dec. 2021) to nearly 3% now.  us_10y_bondyield741×465 29.1 KB  As yields are rising, I’d assume, that this would put pressure on the liquidity of the whole stablecoin market. I hope I didn’t miss anything in the Maker community in the last months, so correct me if I’m wrong:  dai_supply1407×665 50 KB  The falling dai supply and also the falling collateralization of DAI via stables isn’t surprising for me in this case. However I still don’t understand a few governance mechanisms and why DAI to USD isn’t already reacting. If liquidity moves out, I’d assume price of DAI/USD would be much greater influenced. However price movement is rather normal. Idk what I get wrong: If there is actually demand to unlock USDC as collateral and leave the system, it would actually mean that there is demand to sell DAI for USDC or USD. In this mind example DAI/USD would fall below 1 (USD would become stronger against DAI) which it doesn’t really do.  dai_usd977×885 58.7 KB  So do liquidations of DAI against crypto collateral (which are quite deflationary for DAI) and yield oriented capital flows (USD leaving to get yield on the treasury market) create a state of equilibrium right now? Did times change due to the high collateralization via other stables? Don’t get me wrong, I don’t want something like 2020 to happen again ;). I’m simply asking myself what I’m getting wrong. I’d assume the following along the path if yields keep rising: More capital would leave the system and DAI would fall in value against the dollar. In order to counter that, Maker would have to raise saving rates to counter the depreciation against the dollar and defend its pegging. As rates for DAI would rise, this would also have severe implications for the crypto market. IMO the monetary tools of the FED must have implications on the market at some point, however I don’t see it anywhere in the stats of DAI except in the falling supply. From a logic point of view I can’t get another explanation. Even if we go back to the days of gold pegging during the financial crisis, where central banks had to hike rates to defend their gold standard against capital outflows, it was the same mechanism. Is the treasury movement still to low for something like that to happen with the DAI savings rate? Thx for your replies in advance.

DAI doesn’t exactly have a floating exchange rate currently. It’s partially pegged via the PSM that’s currently sitting at $4B USDC (with a max at $5.5B USDC in the past). The PSM might be a better look at equilibrium flows for the DAI price. Rather than the shrinking DAI Total Supply which can have a net zero effect because of shrinking debt too.  PSMUSDC1098×631 46.3 KB     makerburn.com    makerburn.com Dashboard for watching DAI minting and MKR token burning in real time.      You’re correct that rates and the DSR would need to be raised if there’s more depletion of the PSM to defend the peg from downward movement.

Thx for your explanation. That makes sense now. I’ll summarize it to get it right: The movement of DAI/USD depends mainly on the movement USDC/USD now. Since it is a pegged stable, DAI hardly moves , although the 10y is at 3%. The more interesting number is the collateralization of the PSM module now. If it sinks to some point, Maker would raise rates, to counter it, right? Is there a number, you’d be worried? Does it also depend on the speed of depletion? Is it programmed somewhere or decided via governance?

I think the fed funds rate and short term yields matter more than 10y.  Once savings accounts are giving 1,2+%, I imagine there’s no reason to hold dai if you can get that much more yield from a completely risk free and liquid bank account.  But you should still have some kind of demand from those who want to stay in the crypto world and are using dai for things like AMM.  Of course, if the fed wants to suck up all the liquidity out there, they can by going even higher.  It’s kind of what you get for being a stablecoin linked to their currency…  Anyway, this is why I think it’s important that we have the ability to put what’s in our PSMs in short term treasuries.  So that we can redirect their yield into our DSR and take away their power to influence Dai demand.  At high rates, you probably get even more demand for Dai if you can indirectly get people those high yields that are coming very soon.

Metternich:  Is it programmed somewhere or decided via governance?   There’s a Parameter Proposal Group, and they put forth proposals that goes through governance to be approved. Currently there might be a headwind from crypto deleveraging and less demand for crypto loans? That counteracts some of the FED’s draining of liquidity. Also I agree with @Traster_Tray that the short term Fed Funds Rate is a better indicator than the 10yr Treasury.

Traster_Tray:  Once savings accounts are giving 1,2+%, I imagine there’s no reason to hold dai if you can get that much more yield from a completely risk free and liquid bank account.   Rising yields does not necessarily mean it’s a good thing for your local bank savings account. Depends on the Net interest margin (the spread, between the cost of loans and what they make) of the bank. Also large banks are currently flushed with too much cash—they would prefer to shrink—some have been pushing deposits out—too much cash kills their equity returns.

Agree @flipflopflapdelegate, but on this I must say there is abundant research on the benefits for RoE of banks of rising interest rates. However we all hope that now, faced by way more capital efficient rails like DeFi, those same banks will have difficulties in protecting their pricing power against depositors and borrowers. I am a natural optimist.

Yes, some of the bigger banks may not raise rates and just take the difference in profit but there are many, many smaller online-only banks out there fighting for deposits and I think this week you’ll see many of them almost immediately raise their rates as soon as the fed announces their rate decision.  Seeing as we’re talking about people who have found a way to have Dai, my guess is that they wouldn’t have much of a problem transferring to these savings accounts.
